intro: Salvia glechomoides, commonly known as Mexican sage, is a perennial herb native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Its flowers are violet to blue in color, arranged in dense whorls along the stems, and bloom from late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping.
